manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: Creates an arrow line of any angle by clicking and dragging your mouse from the beginning to the end of the line. The line will be drawn in the red color. This color can be changed from the Annotation Settings.
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: Creates four lines that identify the price levels. The percentages are 0, 100, 127.20 and 161.80 [%]. The fibonacci extension will be drawn in the red color. This color can be changed from the Annotation Settings.

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: Creates four lines that identify the price levels. The retracement percentages are 0, 38.20, 61.80 and 100 [%]. The fibonacci retracement will be drawn in the red color. This color can be changed from the Annotation Settings.

The horizontal line will be drawn in the red color. This color can be changed from the Annotation Settings.

The annotation stores the date from it's position and will move along the Date Axis; The vertical line will be drawn in the red color. This color can be changed from the Annotation Settings.

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.commonshttpclient > 1.3.0, org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.dialogs > 7.15.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: The Price Oscillator shows the difference between two moving averages. It is basically a MACD, but the Price Oscillator can use any time periods. A buy signal is generated when the Price Oscillator rises above zero and a sell signal is generated when it falls below zero.
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The Accumulation/Distribution Line is similar to the On Balance Volume (OBV), which sums the volume times +1/-1 based on whether the close is higher than the previous close. The Accumulation/Distribution indicator, however multiplies the volume by the close location value (CLV). The CLV is based on the movement of the issue within a single bar and can be +1, -1 or zero.
The Accumulation/Distribution Line is interpreted by looking for a divergence in the direction of the indicator relative to price. If the Accumulation/Distribution Line is trending upward it indicates that the price may follow. Also, if the Accumulation/Distribution Line becomes flat while the price is still rising (or falling) then it signals an impending flattening of the price.
The Accumulation/Distribution Line was developed by Marc Chaikin.
The Accumulation/Distribution Line should not be confused with the Williams price Accumulation/Distribution indicator.
(source: stockcharts.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4, org.openide.explorer > 6.26, org.openide.nodes > 7.14, org.openide.util > 8.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.1, org.openide.windows > 6.32

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The Accumulation Distribution Oscillator, sometimes referred to as the Chaikin Oscillator – or Chaikin A/D Oscillator is named after its creator, Marc Chaikin.
The Chaikin Oscillator is simply the Moving Average Convergence Divergence indicator (MACD) applied to the Accumulation/Distribution Line. The formula is the difference between the 3-day exponential moving average and the 10-day exponential moving average of the Accumulation/Distribution Line. Just as the MACD-Histogram is an indicator to predict moving average crossovers in MACD, the Chaikin Oscillator is a single line indicator to predict changes in the Accumulation/Distribution Line.
Many of the same signals that apply to MACD are also applicable to the Chaikin Oscillator. Keep in mind though, that these signals relate to the Accumulation/Distribution Line, not directly to the stock itself. Readers may want to refer to our MACD article for more detailed information on various signals such as positive divergences, negative divergences and centerline crossovers.
(source: stockcharts.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4, org.openide.explorer > 6.26, org.openide.nodes > 7.14, org.openide.util > 8.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.1, org.openide.windows > 6.32

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
Aroon is an indicator system that can be used to determine whether a stock is trending or not and how strong the trend is. "Aroon" means "Dawn's Early Light" in Sanskrit and Chande chose that name for this indicator since it is designed to reveal the beginning of a new trend.
The Aroon indicator system consists of two lines, 'Aroon(up)' and 'Aroon(down)'. It takes a single parameter which is the number of time periods to use in the calculation. Aroon(up) is the amount of time (on a percentage basis) that has elapsed between the start of the time period and the point at which the highest price during that time period occurred. If the stock closes at a new high for the given period, Aroon(up) will be +100. For each subsequent period that passes without another new high, Aroon(up) moves down by an amount equal to (1 / # of periods) x 100.
(source: stockcharts.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4, org.openide.explorer > 6.26, org.openide.nodes > 7.14, org.openide.util > 8.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.1, org.openide.windows > 6.32

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The ADX is a Welles Wilder style moving average of the Directional Movement Index (DX). The values range from 0 to 100, but rarely get above 60. To interpret the ADX, consider a high number to be a strong trend, and a low number, a weak trend.
See also +/-DI, DX and ADXR.
The ADX was developed by J. Welles Wilder and is described in his 1978 book New Concepts In Technical Trading Systems.
(source: fmlabs.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4, org.openide.explorer > 6.26, org.openide.nodes > 7.14, org.openide.util > 8.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.1, org.openide.windows > 6.32

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The ADXR is equal to the current ADX plus the ADX from n bars ago divided by 2. In effect, it is the average of the two ADX values. The ADXR smoothes the ADX, and is therefore less responsive, however, the ADXR filters out excessive tops and bottoms. To interpret the ADXR, consider a high number to be a strong trend, and a low number, a weak trend.
(source: fmlabs.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4, org.openide.explorer > 6.26, org.openide.nodes > 7.14, org.openide.util > 8.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.1, org.openide.windows > 6.32

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
Average True Range (ATR) indicator is a volatility measure. As with most of his indicators, Wilder designed ATR with commodities and daily prices in mind. In 1978, commodities were frequently more volatile than stocks. They were (and still are) often subject to gaps and limit moves. A limit move occurs when a commodity opens up or down its maximum allowed move for the session. A volatility formula based only on the high-low range would fail to capture volatility from gap or limit moves. Wilder created Average True Range to capture this "missing" volatility. It is important to remember that ATR does not provide an indication of price direction, just volatility.
(source: stockcharts.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4, org.openide.explorer > 6.22.1.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.12.1.1, org.openide.util > 7.31.1.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.1, org.openide.windows > 6.30.1
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Short-Description: Draws an Average True Range indicator

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The balance of power (BOP) indicator measures the strength of the bulls vs. bears by assessing the ability of each to push price to an extreme level.
(source: iqbroker.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4, org.openide.explorer > 6.26, org.openide.nodes > 7.14, org.openide.util > 8.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.1, org.openide.windows > 6.32

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: The SVE_BB%b indicator is often a leading indicator making smooth moves with clear turning points. It is an ideal tool to help you find the entry and exit points while watching price moving between the Bollinger bands.
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The Chande Momentum Oscillator is a modified RSI. Where the RSI divides the upward movement by the net movement (up / (up + down)), the CMO divides the total movement by the net movement ((up - down) / (up + down)).
There are several ways to interpret the CMO. Values over 50 indicate overbought conditions, while values under -50 indicate oversold conditions. High CMO values indicate strong trends. When the CMO crosses above a moving average of the CMO, it is a buy signal, crossing down is a sell signal.
(source: fmlabs.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4, org.openide.explorer > 6.26, org.openide.nodes > 7.14, org.openide.util > 8.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.1, org.openide.windows > 6.32

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
Commodity Channel Index (CCI) was designed to identify cyclical turns in commodities. The assumption behind the indicator is that commodities (or stocks or bonds) move in cycles, with highs and lows coming at periodic intervals. Lambert recommended using 1/3 of a complete cycle (low to low or high to high) as a time frame for the CCI. (Note: Determination of the cycle's length is independent of the CCI.) If the cycle runs 60 days (a low about every 60 days), then a 20-day CCI would be recommended. For the purpose of this example, a 20-day CCI is used.
(source: stockcharts.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The +DI is the percentage of the true range that is up. The -DI is the percentage of the true range that is down. A buy signal is generated when the +DI crosses up over the -DI. A sell signal is generated when the -DI crosses up over the +DI. You should wait to enter a trade until the extreme point is reached. That is, you should wait to enter a long trade until the price reaches the high of the bar on which the +DI crossed over the -DI, and wait to enter a short trade until the price reaches the low of the bar on which the -DI crossed over the +DI.
See also DX, ADX and ADXR.
The DI was developed by J. Welles Wilder and is described in his 1978 book New Concepts In Technical Trading Systems.
(source:fmlabs.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The +DI is the percentage of the true range that is up. The -DI is the percentage of the true range that is down. A buy signal is generated when the +DI crosses up over the -DI. A sell signal is generated when the -DI crosses up over the +DI. You should wait to enter a trade until the extreme point is reached. That is, you should wait to enter a long trade until the price reaches the high of the bar on which the +DI crossed over the -DI, and wait to enter a short trade until the price reaches the low of the bar on which the -DI crossed over the +DI.
See also DX, ADX and ADXR.
The DI was developed by J. Welles Wilder and is described in his 1978 book New Concepts In Technical Trading Systems.
(source:fmlabs.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1
org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The first part of Welles Wilder's Directional Movement System. You can also use ADX or DMI with the system since they both take into account the following for Wilder's +/-DM
+DM = Today's High - Yesterday's High (when price moves upward) -DM = Yesterday's Low - Today's Low (when price moves downward) You cannot have both +DM and -DM on the same day. If there is an outside day (where both calculations are positive) then the larger of the two results is taken. An inside day (where both calculations are negative) will always equal zero.
See Average Directional Index (ADX) or Directional Movement Indicator (DMI) for a complete indicator that lends a more complete picure to tradeable systems or use this single, simple calculation for experimentation.
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The Directional Movement Index (also known as DMI) is a momentum indicator that was developed by J. Welles Wilder. It is calculated using the price, compares the current price with the previous price range, and displays the result as an upward movement line (+DI), and a downward movement line (-DI), between 0 and 100. The DMI also calculates the strength of the upward or downward movement, and displays the result as a trend strength line (ADX).
(source: daytrading.about.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The force index is a technical analysis indicator, that calculates the strength of a price change using a combination of the prices and the volume. The force index is displayed as a single line that oscillates above and below zero, and it therefore looks similar to other oscillating indicators such as the Commodity Channel Index. However, the force index is different from most indicators in that it uses the price change, the direction of the price change, and the volume.
(source: daytrading.about.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: You can use this indicator to see whether the market is in a cycle mode or trend mode.
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The basic concept behind this indicator is that to follow changes in the Market your indicators should be constantly tuned (by changing their period) to the current main movement of the Market (Dominant Cycle). Given that you know the Dominant Cycle you can adjust your indicators and get clean signals.
The period of your indicators shall be adjusted to half of the lenght of the Dominant Cycle. For example if DHT shows a Dominant Cycle = 27.8 then you should tune your indicators to 14 bars.
(source: forex.forexdigitalsolutions.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4, org.openide.explorer > 6.26, org.openide.nodes > 7.14, org.openide.util > 8.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.1, org.openide.windows > 6.32

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: The Hilbert Transform Trendline
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4, org.openide.explorer > 6.26, org.openide.nodes > 7.14, org.openide.util > 8.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.1, org.openide.windows > 6.32

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: The Hilbert Transform Trend Mode Indicator
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4, org.openide.explorer > 6.26, org.openide.nodes > 7.14, org.openide.util > 8.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.1, org.openide.windows > 6.32

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
MAMA is the mother of all adaptive moving averages. Actualy the name is an acronym for MESA Adaptive Moving Average. The nonlinear action of this filter is produced by the flyback of phase every half cycle. When combined with FAMA, a Following Adaptive Moving Average, the crossovers form excellent entry and exit signals that are relative free of whipsaws.
(source: www.mesasoftware.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4, org.openide.explorer > 6.26, org.openide.nodes > 7.14, org.openide.util > 8.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.1, org.openide.windows > 6.32

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The Momentum is a measurement of the acceleration and deceleration of prices. It indicates if prices are increasing at an increasing rate or decreasing at a decreasing rate. The Momentum function can be applied to the price, or to any other data series.
Momentum has three weaknesses:
1. It does not fluctuate between set limits, meaning that Overbought and Oversold levels have to be re-set for each stock; 2. Movements tend to be erratic; and 3. Unusually high or low prices at the start of the indicator window (e.g. 14 days ago on a 14 day indicator) cause distortion.
Momentum is one of the 4 most commonly used momentum oscillators. The following are descriptions of the other 3:
Rate of Change fluctuates as a percentage around the zero line, but the indicator still suffers from the last two weaknesses.
RSI addresses all three weaknesses: it is smoother, not as susceptible to distortion and fluctuates between 0 and 100.
Stochastic indicator compares closing price to the price range (High minus Low) for the window period. This is an improvement on the above three indicators which measure relative changes in closing price. Stochastic movements can be erratic and many analysts use the internally-smoothed Slow Stochastic indicator, which they find more reliable.
(source: investopedia.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
Calculated by averaging the high, low, and closing prices, and multiplying by the daily volume. Comparing that result with the number for the previous day tells you whether money flow was positive or negative for the current day. When a stock is purchased at a higher price (an uptick), this is considered positive money flow. When the next trade is at a lower price (a downtick), this is considered to be negative money flow. If more shares were bought throughout the day on the uptick than the downtick, net money flow is positive because more investors were willing to pay a premium for the stock. If money flow is negative when a stock's price is rising, this could spell trouble.
(source: investopedia.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The Money Flow Index (MFI) is a momentum indicator that is similar to the Relative Strength Index (RSI) in both interpretation and calculation. However, MFI is a more rigid indicator in that it is volume-weighted, and is therefore a good measure of the strength of money flowing in and out of a security. It compares "positive money flow" to "negative money flow" to create an indicator that can be compared to price in order to identify the strength or weakness of a trend. Like the RSI, the MFI is measured on a 0 - 100 scale and is often calculated using a 14 day period.
(source: stockcharts.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Short-Description: Draws a money flow index indicator

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
Moving Average Convergence-Divergence (MACD) is one of the simplest and most effective momentum indicators available. MACD turns two trend-following indicators, moving averages, into a momentum oscillator by subtracting the longer moving average from the shorter moving average. As a result, MACD offers the best of both worlds: trend following and momentum. MACD fluctuates above and below the zero line as the moving averages converge, cross and diverge. Traders can look for signal line crossovers, centerline crossovers and divergences to generate signals. Because MACD is unbounded, it is not particularly useful for identifying overbought and oversold levels.
(source: stockcharts.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Short-Description: Draws a moving average convergence/divergence indicator

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The idea behind N-ATR (or Corey’s ATR Percentage) is to make ATR directly comparable between trading instruments of different price levels – or when you’re looking at something over a long time period where prices have changed a lot. It provides a very clean way to assess the potential value of an investment between different stocks or commodities that are priced at different ranges (example: Stock 1: $6.30 and Stock 2: $43.55, which one might be the better investment based on the N-ATR?)
(source:http://www.theessentialsoftrading.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: The Normalized Volatility Indicator (NVI) determines when the market is in a bull or bear phase.
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Short-Description: Draws a Normalized Volatility Indicator indicator

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The On Balance Volume (OBV) is a cumulative total of the up and down volume. When the close is higher than the previous close, the volume is added to the running total, and when the close is lower than the previous close, the volume is subtracted from the running total. To interpret the OBV, look for the OBV to move with the price or precede price moves. If the price moves before the OBV, then it is a non-confirmed move. A series of rising peaks, or falling troughs, in the OBV indicates a strong trend. If the OBV is flat, then the market is not trending.
(source: fmlabs.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Short-Description: Draws an On Balance Volume indicator

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The PPO and the moving average convergence divergence (MACD) are both momentum indicators that measure the difference between the 26-day and the nine-day exponential moving averages. The main difference between these indicators is that the MACD reports the simple difference between the exponential moving averages, whereas the PPO expresses this difference as a percentage. This allows a trader to use the PPO indicator to compare stocks with different prices more easily. For example, regardless of the stock's price, a PPO result of 10 means the short-term average is 10% above the long-term average.
(source: www.investopedia.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: This is the classic way to calculate the rate of change. See also the description of Rate of Change - Ratio for meore details.
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: The Rate of Change represented as a percent. This is also the most usual way it which it is referenced though it is not the only way to measure rate of change. See also the Rate of Change - Ratio description for more details
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
Rate of Change Ratio compares today's closing price to a closing price X days ago, as chosen by the trader. There are several variations of the rate of change formula. The following is the calculation for this version:
RoC = Today's Closing Price / Closing price X days ago
ROC is sometimes confused with momentum but they are different calculations. Momentum is itself an important mathematical means of ascertaining the speed of the market's change. Momentum, however, subtracts the previous day's closing price from that of today:
Momentum = Today's closing price - Closing price X days ago.
There are three other types of calculations for ROC:
ROC Percentage (price-prevPrice)/prevPrice
ROC Ratio x 100 (price/prevPrice) * 100
Rate of Change ((price/prevPrice)-1)*100)
(source: www.investopedia.com in part)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
Rate of Change Ratio x100 is the Rate of change Ratio Indicator mulitplied by 100.
See Rate of Change - Ratio
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Short-Description: Rate of Change - Ratio x100 Indicator

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The Relative Strength Index (RSI) calculates a ratio of the recent upward price movements to the absolute price movement. The RSI ranges from 0 to 100. The RSI is interpreted as an overbought/oversold indicator when the value is over 70/below 30. You can also look for divergence with price. If the price is making new highs/lows, and the RSI is not, it indicates a reversal.
(source: fmlabs.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Short-Description: Draws a relative strength index indicator

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
This indicator gives clear entry and exit signals, making it easier to make your entry and exit decisions. The clear entry and exit signals given by SRIFT can make your decision to buy or sell a lot easier. I would encourage you to try this method on several charts. I am confident you will see an improvement in your trading results.
(source: Technical Analysis of STOCKS & COMMODITIES)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Short-Description: Smoothed RSI Inverse Fisher Transform Indicator Plugin

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
As with any oscillator, the Spearman indicator can remain above overbought (+80) and below oversold (-80) levels for longer periods of time when uptrends or downtrends are particularly strong. This indicator rarely records extreme values of +100 and -100. In those cases when it does happen, it is safe to bet against the existing trend. The crossings with the short moving average (3-day SMA) point to the end of trends and formation of minor or major turning points. Another way to use this indicator its is position in relation with zero. Promising long entries are taken just when the Spearman indicator crosses zero coming from below. On the other side, short positions carry a higher degree of confidence when the indicator falls below zero. A good deal of the trend can be lost, but the entries are more secure.
(source: Technical Analysis of STOCKS & COMMODITIES)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The Stochastic Oscillator is a technical indicator which compares a stock's closing price to its price range over a given period of time. The belief is that in rising market stocks will close near their highs, while in a falling market they will close near their lows.
Both the Fast Stochastic and Slow Stochastic oscillators are used by market technicians as a timing indicator for signals of market reversal. The Fast Stochastic will provide more signals (i.e. less smoother) than the Slow Stochastic, although some analysts prefer the Slow Stochastic, believing it is less prone to whipsaws.
(source: alphatrade.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The Stochastic Oscillator is a technical indicator which compares a stock's closing price to its price range over a given period of time. The belief is that in rising market stocks will close near their highs, while in a falling market they will close near their lows.
Both the Fast Stochastic and Slow Stochastic oscillators are used by market technicians as a timing indicator for signals of market reversal. The Fast Stochastic will provide more signals (i.e. less smoother) than the Slow Stochastic, although some analysts prefer the Slow Stochastic, believing it is less prone to whipsaws.
(source: www.alphatrade.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
Stochastic RSI (StochRSI) is an indicator of an indicator. It calculates the RSI relative to its range in order to increase the sensitivity of the standard RSI. The values of the StochRSI are from zero to one.
The Stochastic RSI can be interpreted several ways. Overbought/oversold conditions are indicated when the StochRSI crosses above .20 / below .80. A buy signal is generated when the StochRSI moves from oversold to above the midpoint (.50). A sell signal is generated when the StochRSI moves from overbought to below the midpoint. Also look for divergence with the price to indicate the end of a trend.
(source: fmlabs.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: The Stochastics Oscillator is a momentum indicator that shows the location of the current close relative to the high/low range over a number of periods. Closing values near the top of the range indicate accumulation and those near the bottom of the range indicate distribution.
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The TRIX indicator calculates the rate of change of a triple exponential moving average. The values oscillate around zero. Buy/sell signals are generated when the TRIX crosses above/below zero. A (typically) 9 period exponential moving average of the TRIX can be used as a signal line. A buy/sell signals are generated when the TRIX crosses above/below the signal line and is also above/below zero.
(source: www.fmlabs.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The Ultimate Oscillator is the weighted sum of three oscillators of different time periods. The typical time periods are 7, 14 and 28. The values of the Ultimate Oscillator range from zero to 100. Values over 70 indicate overbought conditions, and values under 30 indicate oversold conditions. Also look for agreement/divergence with the price to confirm a trend or signal the end of a trend.
(source: fmlabs.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: Creates a Volume indicator that represents the number of shares traded every day. The indicator is a histogram drawn on the bottom of the chart.
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: The Williams %R is similar to an unsmoothed Stochastic %K. The values range from zero to 100. Values below 20 indicate an overbought condition and a sell signal is generated when it crosses the 20 line. Values over 80 indicate an oversold condition and a buy signal is generated when it crosses the 80 line.
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
Commons Codec provides implementations of common encoders and decoders such as Base64, Hex, Phonetic and URLs.
(source: apache.org)

The Hyper-Text Transfer Protocol (HTTP) is perhaps the most significant protocol used on the Internet today. Web services, network-enabled appliances and the growth of network computing continue to expand the role of the HTTP protocol beyond user-driven web browsers, while increasing the number of applications that require HTTP support. Designed for extension while providing robust support for the base HTTP protocol, the HttpClient component may be of interest to anyone building HTTP-aware client applications such as web browsers, web service clients, or systems that leverage or extend the HTTP protocol for distributed communication.
(source: apache.org)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.commonscodec > 1.3.0, org.chartsy.commonslogging > 1.3.0

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The Logging package is an ultra-thin bridge between different logging implementations. A library that uses the commons-logging API can be used with any logging implementation at runtime. Commons-logging comes with support for a number of popular logging implementations, and writing adapters for others is a reasonably simple task.
(source: apache.org)
Facebook Java Library
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.commonslogging > 1.3.0

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
SwingX contains a collection of powerful, useful, and just plain fun Swing components. Each of the Swing components have been extended, providing data-aware functionality out of the box. New useful components have been created like the JXDatePicker, JXTaskPane, and JXImagePanel.
(source: swinglabs.org)

TA-Lib is widely used by trading software developers requiring to perform technical analysis of financial market data. It includes 200 indicators such as ADX, MACD, RSI, Stochastic, Bollinger Bands, and many more. Candlestick pattern recognition is also part of the library. It is an open-source API for C/C++, Java, Perl, Python and 100% Managed .NET. See http://www.ta-lib.org

This library is intended to ease image uploads to TwitPic by handling the construction of multipart/form-data POST requests. The library offers methods for both the "upload" and "uploadAndPost" TwitPic API calls. It's extremely easy to use and designed to be lightweight.
(Source: twitpic4j)

The Favorites module provides a screen with information about the most used stocks. The screen appears when you start the application for the first time. You can open new charts directly from this screen.
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.netbeans.modules.queries/1 > 1.19.1, org.netbeans.modules.settings/1 > 1.26.1, org.openide.actions > 6.16.1, org.openide.awt > 7.23.1, org.openide.dialogs > 7.15.1, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.filesystems > 7.38.1, org.openide.loaders > 7.16.1, org.openide.modules > 7.17.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Short-Description: Shows favorites content after the first startup of the application.

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: This is the main module. Here is the core of the application.
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.commonshttpclient > 1.3.0, org.chartsy.facebookapi > 2.1.0, org.chartsy.swingx > 1.0, org.chartsy.twitpicapi > 4.0, org.netbeans.api.progress/1 > 1.20.1, org.netbeans.core.output2/1 > 1.18.1, org.netbeans.modules.core.kit > 1.8.1, org.netbeans.modules.options.api/1 > 1.18.1, org.netbeans.modules.print > 7.5.1, org.netbeans.modules.settings/1 > 1.26.1, org.netbeans.swing.tabcontrol > 1.21.1, org.openide.actions > 6.16.1, org.openide.awt > 7.23.1, org.openide.dialogs > 7.15.1, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.filesystems > 7.38.1, org.openide.loaders > 7.16.1, org.openide.modules > 7.17.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: Provides updates for BTC Trader
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.commonslogging > 1.3.0, org.netbeans.modules.autoupdate.services > 1.20.1, org.openide.filesystems > 7.38.1, org.openide.modules > 7.17.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
Bollinger Bands are volatility bands placed above and below a moving average. Volatility is based on the standard deviation, which changes a volatility increase and decreases. The bands automatically widen when volatility increases and narrow when volatility decreases. This dynamic nature of Bollinger Bands also means they can be used on different securities with the standard settings. For signals, Bollinger Bands can be used to identify M-Tops and W-Bottoms or to determine the strength of the trend.
(source: stockcharts.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1
org.chartsy.main > 1.4.1, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The DEMA is a smoothing indicator with less lag than a straight exponential moving average. DEMA is an acronym for Double Exponential Moving Average, but the calculation is more complex than just a moving average of a moving average.
The DEMA was developed by Patrick Mulloy and is described in his article in the February, 1994 issue of Technical Analysis of Stocks & Commodities magazine.
See also Exponential MA, Least Squares MA, Simple MA, Triangular MA, Weighted MA, Welles MA, Variable MA, Volume Adjusted MA, Zero Lag Exponential MA, TEMA and T3.
(source: fmlabs.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4, org.openide.explorer > 6.26, org.openide.nodes > 7.14, org.openide.util > 8.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.1, org.openide.windows > 6.32
org.chartsy.main > 1.4.1, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The Exponential Moving Average is a staple of technical analysis and is used in countless technical indicators. In a Simple Moving Average, each value in the time period carries equal weight, and values outside of the time period are not included in the average. However, the Exponential Moving Average is a cumulative calculation, including all data. Past values have a diminishing contribution to the average, while more recent values have a greater contribution. This method allows the moving average to be more responsive to changes in the data.
(source: fmlabs.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1
org.chartsy.main > 1.4.1, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
Developed by Perry Kaufman, this indicator is a moving average that automatically adjusts its speed based on market volatility.
The KAMA can be used in place of traditional moving averages.
(source: vtsystems.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4, org.openide.explorer > 6.26, org.openide.nodes > 7.14, org.openide.util > 8.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.1, org.openide.windows > 6.32

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The Linear Regression indicator is based on the trend of a security's price over a specified time period. The trend is determined by calculating a linear regression trendline using the "least squares fit" method. The least squares fit technique fits a trendline to the data in the chart by minimizing the distance between the data points and the linear regression trendline.
Any point along the Linear Regression indicator is equal to the ending value of a Linear Regression trendline. For example, the ending value of a Linear Regression trendline that covers 10 days will have the same value as a 10-day Linear Regression indicator. This differs slightly from the Time Series Forecast indicator in that the TSF adds the slope to the ending value of the regression line. This makes the TSF a bit more responsive to short term price changes. If you plot the TSF and the Linear Regression indicator side-by-side, you’ll notice that the TSF hugs the prices more closely than the Linear Regression indicator.
Rather than plotting a straight Linear Regression trendline, the Linear Regression indicator plots the ending values of multiple Linear Regression trendlines.
This is different than most linear regression algorithims you'll find in other charting applications
(source: www.paritech.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1
org.chartsy.main > 1.4.1, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The Parabolic SAR calculates a trailing stop. Simply exit when the price crosses the SAR. The SAR assumes that you are always in the market, and calculates the Stop And Reverse point when you would close a long position and open a short position or vice versa.
Developed by the creator of RSI and DMI, the Parabolic SAR sets trailing price stops for long or short positions. Also referred to as the stop-and-reversal indicator (SAR stands for "stop and reversal"), Parabolic SAR is more popular for setting stops than for establishing direction or trend. Wilder recommended establishing the trend first, and then trading with Parabolic SAR in the direction of the trend. If the trend is up, buy when the indicator moves below the price. If the trend is down, sell when the indicator moves above the price.
The Parabolic SAR was developed by J. Welles Wilder and is described in his 1978 book, New Concepts In Technical Trading Systems.
(source: stockcharts.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4, org.openide.explorer > 6.26, org.openide.nodes > 7.14, org.openide.util > 8.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.1, org.openide.windows > 6.32

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
Moving Averages are used to smooth the data in an array to help eliminate noise and identify trends. The Simple Moving Average is literally the simplest form of a moving average. Each output value is the average of the previous n values. In a Simple Moving Average, each value in the time period carries equal weight, and values outside of the time period are not included in the average. This makes it less responsive to recent changes in the data, which can be useful for filtering out those changes.
(source: fmlabs.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The T3 Moving Average was described by Tim Tillson in the January 1998 issue of Technical Analysis of Stocks & Commodities article "Smoothing Techniques for More Accurate Signals". The T3 is a significant improvement over traditional moving averages; it's smoother with much less lag. However, it can "overshoot" price as it attempts to re-align itself with current market prices.
The T3 Moving Average can be used in place of traditional moving averages.
(source: vtsystems.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4, org.openide.explorer > 6.26, org.openide.nodes > 7.14, org.openide.util > 8.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.1, org.openide.windows > 6.32

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
This pattern is divided into the following two categories: - Three-bar inside bar positive reversal - Three-bar inside bar negative reversal If an inside bar formed inside two higher closes, then it is considered to be a three-bar inside bar positive reversal. If an inside bar formed inside two lower closes, then it is considered to be a three-bar inside bar negative reversal. This three-bar inside bar strategy tends to enter long or short during any type of trend. However, the system also tends to hold losing trades for the same percentage as profitable trades hold. If you try using different types of exits such as trailing stops or average true range, it could result in higher profits. Crude oil performed well in long trades and silver performed well in short trades, so applying any filters in your entries could change your performance results. The drawdowns of initial capital of this system when trading gold and silver were only 10%. Crude oil, however, had a drawdown of 17%.
(source: Technical Analysis of STOCKS & COMMODITIES)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The Time Series Forecast indicator is based on the trend of a security's price over a specified time period. The trend is determined by calculating a linear regression trendline using the "least squares fit" method. The least squares fit technique fits a trendline to the data in the chart by minimizing the distance between the data points and the linear regression trendline.
Any point along the Time Series Forecast is equal to the ending value of a Linear Regression trendline plus its slope. For example, the ending value of a Linear Regression trendline (plus its slope) that covers 10 days will have the same value as a 10-day Time Series Forecast. This differs slightly from the Linear Regression indicator in that the Linear Regression indicator does not add the slope to the ending value of the regression line. This makes the TSF a bit more responsive to short term price changes. If you plot the TSF and the Linear Regression indicator side-by-side, you’ll notice that the TSF hugs the prices more closely than the Linear Regression indicator.
(source: www.paritech.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The Triangular Moving Average is a form of Weighted Moving Average wherein the weights are assigned in a triangular pattern. For example, the weights for a 7 period Triangular Moving Average would be 1, 2, 3, 4, 3, 2, 1. This gives more weight to the middle of the time series and less weight to the oldest and newest data.
The Triangular Moving Average is mathematically equivalent to a Simple Moving Average of a Simple Moving Average.
See also Exponential MA, Least Squares MA, Simple MA, Weighted MA, Welles MA, Variable MA, Volume Adjusted MA, Zero Lag Exponential MA, DEMA, TEMA and T3.
(source: fmlabs.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.14, org.openide.util > 8.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.1, org.openide.windows > 6.32

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: The Triple Exponential Moving Average (TEMA) is an unique combination of a single exponential moving average, a double exponential moving average and a triple exponential moving average. TEMA is an oscillator which follows overbought and oversold markets.
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Short-Description: Draws a triple exponential moving average

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
This analysis should be based on a weekly chart.
The first part of the strategy is used by many traders: - buy when the slow RSI(17) rises above its 60-level and the price is above its 40-week simple moving average. - sell when the slow RSI(17) falls below its 40-level and the price is below its 40-week simple moving average.
This makes you stay long in the uptrend, and out in a downtrend. During a downtrend - as defined by the slow RSI(17) - it should be possible to trade the minor corrections, although you should be aware you are trading against the main trend.
If the slow RSI(17) signals a downtrend: - buy when the quick RSI(5) rises above its 60-level and the price is above its 10-week simple moving average and the slow RSI(17) signals a downtrend. - sell when the quick RSI(5) falls below its 40-level and the price is below its 10-week simple moving average.
(source: Technical Analysis of STOCKS & COMMODITIES)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The Typical Price is the average of the high + low + close of a bar. It is used in the calculation of several indicators. It can be used to smooth an indicator that normally takes just the closing price as input.
(source: www.fmlabs.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: This module draws the volume bars over the chart.
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
VWAP stands for Volume-Weighted Average Price, the ratio of the value traded to total volume traded over a particular time horizon (usually one session). It is a measure of the average price a stock traded at over the trading horizon. It's calculated by summing the price & volume of each bar or tick, over the entire session, and then dividing that by the sum of the volume for the session.
The VWAP Indicator now has options to draw one or two bands around the VWAP, as well as a variety of options for computing those bands.
(source: linnsoft.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Short-Description: Draws the Volume Weighted Average Price Overlay

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The Weighted Close is the average of the high, low and close of a bar, but the close is weighted, actually counted twice. It is used in the calculation of several indicators. It can be used to smooth an indicator that normally takes just the closing price as input.
(source: www.fmlabs.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4.0, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.16.1, org.openide.util > 8.6.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.3.1, org.openide.windows > 6.33.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The Weighted Moving Average calculates a weight for each value in the series. The more recent values are assigned greater weights. The Weighted Moving Average is similar to a Simple Moving average in that it is not cumulative, that is, it only includes values in the time period (unlike an Exponential Moving Average). The Weighted Moving Average is similar to an Exponential Moving Average in that more recent data has a greater contribution to the average.
See also Exponential MA, Least Squares MA, Simple MA, Triangular MA, Welles MA, Variable MA, Volume Adjusted MA, Zero Lag Exponential MA, DEMA, TEMA and T3.
(source: fmlabs.com)
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.chartsy.main > 1.4.0, org.chartsy.talib > 0.4, org.openide.explorer > 6.28.1, org.openide.nodes > 7.14, org.openide.util > 8.1, org.openide.util.lookup > 8.1, org.openide.windows > 6.32

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The Zig Zag filters out small movements in price to highlight trends. It looks for price moves greater than the threshold level and plots straight lines between those points. The Zig Zag is more of a visual tool than an indicator. It is non-predictive, in fact, the formula looks forward in time to find the zig zag points. The purpose of the Zig Zag is to make chart patterns clearer.
(source: fmlabs.com)
